page.title: 05Conservation-Henwood,Eaton
page.content: Most of the farmers are concerned about the environment, there are no prairie-sized fields, the old field names and field boundaries have survived. In some stock rearing areas {hedgerows} have been replaced by wire fencing. In Eaton there were complaints that shelter had been lost because too much hedging had been removed. One villager showed burn marks on her arms said to have been caused by sprays blowing onto her. All the elm trees have disappeared as the{Dutch Elm disease}killed them. Straw burning is now rigorously controlled, but because straw will not rot easily when turned into the clay soil farmers prefer to burn and gain the potash. Because there are no sheep cereal farmers are not worried by foxes so the hunt is not allowed on their land.
